He conflated civil courts and criminal ones. He conflated Ontarian provincial law with federal law. His position changed constantly with no acknowledgement whatsoever of his errors.

I ran a fact-check from the various statements Peterson made at the subsequent debates around Bill C-16 and found that all--literally all--of his statements were either false or mostly false. 

He didn't even appear to understand how Canadian law works.

Jordan Peterson concocted from thin air a fantasy that this law would somehow criminalize the willful misgendering of a trans person. (Even if this were true, which it's not, the idea that the police would corroborate such a complaint is outrageously laughable).

Bill C-16 was a federal law that proposed adding gender identity to its human rights code. Now, these codes are only really restitution for those with the wealth to pursue them in civil court, so they're not even *that* groundbreaking in terms of material consequence.

Long before Peterson published a book, he received his catapult to fame from Canada's assorted white ethno-nationalist reactionaries in September 2016 through a series of histrionic tirades riddled with falsehoods about Bill C-16.

He sits quietly (for the first time) reflecting.

“Huh” he mumbles. Well I guess you’ve given me a lot to think about.

I give him the cheezinest😄 smile I can before grabbing my bag. “We’re all in this together” I say & pat him on the back.

“Yeah” he says. I guess you’re right.

“Let me tell you what’s broken” this commodity trader tells me. 

Unsurprisingly, his answer is corrupt “Indian Chiefs” and “unaccountability”

He, like many others, doesn’t see the answer he seeks is right infrint of him. 

What’s broken, I tell him, is Canada.

Never once do they consider the absurdity of them telling me how to achieve #reconciliation. 

never once do they consider how absurd it would be if I told them how to trade commodities, or design software.

You see, friends & relatives, the problem I encounter w Canadians, again and again, is that they think they can do my job better than me. 

They think they know how to “fix” native peoples and communities. 
 
They know what’s broken & are here to tell me how to fix it.

And then I tell him that I’m going away because I’m actually quite tired. 

Tired of seeing injustices on The National, of having to explain why people are heartbroken over #JusticeforTinaFontaine #justiceforcoltenboushie.

And I talk. Because that’s what I do. 

I tell stories about Canada, and what I’ve seen in my travels. 

I’m honest about the good I see when I work with youth from @CdnRoots. 

I tell him he was robbed of learning about #Indigenous peoples. “We’re actually quite great”, I say

I ask him about what he knows about #Indigenous peoples. “Well bud,” he says as if a caricature of the ignorant Canadian, “my taxes help them more than they’ help themselves, I know that.” 
🙃

He looks shocked that a native guy in a jean jacket is sitting in the lounge. Then embarrassed for having said what he said. 

He’s a commodity trader (whatever that means). 

I ask him about Canada’s history, he admits that he doesn’t know about our shared past.

“Sad” he said, to no one in particular. “These guys gotta get a grip.” 

I tell myself I’m on vacation, a few times, before taking the bait. 

“Yeah” I say, “the province needs to hand over control to #Indigenous child welfare orgs/professionals. What’re they waiting for?”

Was just a story about child welfare in Manitoba on CBC the National. 90% of kids in care are #Indigenous. 

I’m in the international Air Canada lounge ready to get away from stats. like these briefly & the businessman next to me scoffs...

NOTE/ Lest anyone be confused, McCabe is a corroborating witness for Comey because Comey testified to Congress that he *contemporaneously* relayed the content of his meetings with President Trump—which content could be enough to support an Obstruction of Justice charge—to McCabe.

CONCLUSION/ Trump again—it seems—using Sessions to generate a false basis for firing an FBI witness against him is major international news because it's *key* evidence in a possible future criminal proceeding against Sessions and impeachment or criminal proceedings against Trump.

10/ So this Axios story is *further* evidence of Obstruction of Justice against the president, and *further* evidence of a conspiracy to Obstruct Justice on the part of Sessions—who's already being looked at for this because of his fraudulent memo assisting Trump in firing Comey.

9/ So Sessions violated his recusal to try to permanently destroy the credibility of a key witness against Trump in a future criminal proceeding—and may have done so at Trump's direction. (To be frank, *all America* assumes that it was at Trump's explicit or implicit direction.)

8/ If McCabe is knocked out as a credible witness—if not *actually*, then at least in a way Trump's allies in Congress can *claim* during impeachment proceedings—the Comey-Trump tilt may well be a "he said/he said" between Trump and Comey (and Comey's contemporaneous memos, too).

7/ If McCabe is fired, rather than merely retiring—and if he's fired *because of allegations he was somehow "pro-Clinton" during the Clinton email investigation*—his evidentiary value as Jim Comey's chief corroborating witness against Trump is severely damaged. Trump knows this.

6/ But this goes beyond Sessions—possibly at Trump's direction—trying to punish McCabe financially. That would be mere vengeance, and wouldn't get Trump what he really wants here. What he wants is to *discredit McCabe as a witness in any future impeachment proceedings or trials*.

5/ What events would those be? Well—the only time McCabe has been in the news is as *one of the chief witnesses against the President of the United States in a federal felony investigation that could lead to the president's impeachment for Obstruction*. That's kind of a big deal.

4/ Moreover, the effort to fire Andrew McCabe over events that occurred 18 months ago, and to do so just months before he retires, is an obvious attempt to punish McCabe—via loss of his pension—for events that came *long after* his involvement in the Clinton email investigation.

3/ So Sessions—whether he did it of his own volition or at Trump's demand or encouragement—should never have been pressuring the FBI to fire McCabe over McCabe's involvement in the Clinton email investigation, given that that's an election-related matter Sessions is recused from.

2/ You need to know three things about McCabe:
(a) He's due to retire in a few months—and could lose his pension if he's fired.
(b) He's Comey's chief corroborating witness as to Trump's conversations with Comey.
(c) Sessions is recused from all Russia and election-related cases.

@TamaraMStory My first battle in court over my kids, i was represented by a legal aid lawyer who ended up asking me what i was going to do to ensure that i wouldnt have more children that I would have to fight for (in the courts) again. ouch. we need to speak up. thank you for doing so.

Many Anishinaabe families live in poverty. We don’t have thousands or tens of thousands to pay lawyers fees. So most, like I did, we turned to legal aid to help. And they didn’t help. In fact they maybe damage families further by helping CFS to secure crown ward status.

If it wasn’t for my lawyer @KatherineHensel and my support team I don’t think Anthony would be home with me now. And we still have my youngest son who wonders why he is still in foster care. I wonder the same thing, my boy.

I was told I will never get my kids back. All by people who was supposed to be on my side respresenting me. I have to wonder if this is what all Indigenous families are going through when they get legal aid in their CFS cases in Winnipeg?

I saw other parents, all Indigenous, waiting outside, and this legal aid counsel represented a good deal of them. This was my experience for many years. I was told by legal aid to give up. I was told I couldn’t speak in court.

I gave her the phone number for the First Nations child advocate office in Winnipeg. This legal counsel person was very angry at me for doing that. But I watched as the mom was being bullied by a person supposed to represent her.

Last month when I was in court w/ my lawyers on my case, I was outside the courtroom and witnessed a legal aid counsel telling a mother she represented to give up her children to the crown. The mom was crying uncontrollably saying she didn’t want to. I called the mom over.

My son is four. We live in London. But this morning he was scared of America’s guns.

But now I can’t stop thinking about all the people I know in the US who have that same moment with their kids and cannot say that, and the sheer weight of how that must be is staggering. I cannot begin to grasp it.

And he smiles and goes off to play and I look around the classroom and for the first time in a long, long time I thank the god I do not believe in that I live on this grey, sometimes sensible little island.

And I say, because I can say this, but for the first time really understanding how much that matters:

“It’s okay. That doesn’t happen here. This is London, that’s America. We don’t let people have guns.”

When you see leagues pushing for a foothold in other countries, this is why. The universality of sports isn’t just the domain of the Olympics. It’s soccer, it’s basketball and, yes, it’s even pro baseball. 10/11

For 15 minutes, we had a real conversation despite speaking two completely different languages. He barely knows English. I know even less Korean. Baseball -- excuse me: pro baseball -- was the only translator we needed. 9/11

The last player he brought up was Ken Griffey Jr. I tried to run some names by him: Mike Trout, Bryce Harper, Aaron Judge. The only one he knew was Clayton Kershaw. I’m not positive why Kershaw -- probably Hyun-Jin Ryu? -- but he nodded and motioned with his left arm. 8/11
The cabbie wasn’t done. “Sammy Sosa!” he said. I showed him a recent picture of Sosa. His eyebrows jumped. “Sammy Sosa?” he said. 7/11

“Curt Schilling!” he continues, and I’m wondering why he’s naming 2001 Arizona Diamondbacks when it dawns on me: Byung-Hyun Kim was their closer, and when the Diamondbacks were in the World Series, Korean fans tuned in to watch Kim, a native son. 6/11

He continued: “Randy Johnson! Fastball!” Then he put his hands together, spread them apart and made an exploding noise. And I’m pretty sure the cabbie driving me home in Seoul was letting me know that Randy Johnson once destroyed a bird with a fastball. 5/11

Naturally, I say “Pro baseball!” I try to tell him I write about pro baseball! He gives me a quizzical look. I figure our moment is going to end there. Then the cabbie says, “Randy Johnson!” Holy shit! Did he just say Randy Johnson? 4/11

I figure it’s silence the rest of the way. Only he says, “USA?” I say, “Yes.” He nods, and then he looks at me and says, “Pro baseball?” And I have to compose myself for a second, because of all the things for a random cabbie in Seoul to say, I did not expect “Pro baseball.” 3/11

All five of us jam into one -- me shotgun, the rest in back -- and the cab driver is pissed. He’s in his early 60s, probably, with a deep, authoritative voice. He starts barking. All of us go silent. He begrudgingly drives, drops the other four off and heads toward my hotel. 2/11

So I’m in Seoul last night, on the way home from PyeongChang, and I meet a group of three Americans and a Korean who essentially adopt me for the night. They show me around the Hongdae neighborhood, and by the time we’re ready to go home, open cabs are few and far between. 1/11

I’m tweeting from over the Pacific, on my way back to cover baseball, the perfect bridge to that built, of all people, by a cabbie in a city of 10 million. Gamsahamnida, PyeongChang, for being a truly great Olympic host -- and to Seoul, too, for an unforgettable night. 11/11
